channel.title: Generics on Bas-Man's Musings
channel.description: Recent content in Generics on Bas-Man's Musings

item.title: Deconstructing SPF with Rust using Generics
item.description:
As I mentioned in my previous article Deconstructing SPF Records with Rust. There is a case for using generics given the amount of overlap between the different mechanisms.

So in this article I will document how I transitioned from using unique structs for each mechanism, leading to less overall code and other benefits.

While I was considering how best to go about doing generics, I came across this very nice write up on dev.to entitled Rust Generic Types in Method Definitions. It's certainly worth a read.

A Refresher on the issue

Let's revisit some of the code from the previous article. Specifically we will just look at the struct for Include and Ip4:

Include

1#[derive(Default, Debug, Clone)]
2struct Include {
3 qualifier: char,
4 txt: String,
5}

This is pretty straight forward. It holds a qualifier of char, and a txt of String. Other mechanisms in SPF use the exact same basic components. Specifically, A and MX. Redirect also uses the same components, with the qualifier always being + or simply blank. But I need to duplicate this struct definition for each mechanim.

Not only do I need to create the same structs, I also need to then impl the same functions on each struct.

 1impl Include {
 2 fn new(qualifier: char, txt: String) -> Self {
 3 Self { qualifier, txt }
 4 }
 5 fn as_mechanism(&self) -> String {
 6 // rebuild and return the string represensation of a include mechanism
 7 let mut txt = String::new();
 8 if self.qualifier != '+' {
 9 txt.push(self.qualifier);
10 }
11 txt.push_str("include:");
12 txt.push_str(self.txt.as_str());
13 txt
14 }
15 fn is_pass(&self) -> bool {
16 if self.qualifier == '+' {
17 true
18 } else {
19 false
20 }
21 }
22 fn is_fail(&self) -> bool {
23 if self.qualifier == '-' {
24 true
25 } else {
26 false
27 }
28 }
29 fn is_softfail(&self) -> bool {
30 if self.qualifier == '~' {
31 true
32 } else {
33 false
34 }
35 }
36 fn is_neutral(&self) -> bool {
37 if self.qualifier == '?' {
38 true
39 } else {
40 false
41 }
42 }
43}

This also applies to ip4 and ip6

Ip4

 1#[derive(Debug, Clone)]
 2struct Ip4 {
 3 qualifier: char,
 4 ip: IpNetwork,
 5}
 6
 7impl Ip4 {
 8 fn new(qualifier: char, ip: IpNetwork) -> Self {
 9 Self { qualifier, ip }
10 }
11 fn as_string(&self) -> String {
12 self.ip.to_string()
13 }
14 fn as_mechanism(&self) -> String {
15 let mut ip4_string = String::new();
16 if self.qualifier != '+' {
17 ip4_string.push(self.qualifier);
18 }
19 ip4_string.push_str("ip4:");
20 ip4_string.push_str(self.ip.to_string().as_str());
21 ip4_string
22 }
23 fn as_ip(&self) -> IpNetwork {
24 self.ip
25 }
26 fn is_pass(&self) -> bool {
27 if self.qualifier == '+' {
28 true
29 } else {
30 false
31 }
32 }
33 fn is_fail(&self) -> bool {
34 if self.qualifier == '-' {
35 true
36 } else {
37 false
38 }
39 }
40 fn is_softfail(&self) -> bool {
41 if self.qualifier == '~' {
42 true
43 } else {
44 false
45 }
46 }
47 fn is_neutral(&self) -> bool {
48 if self.qualifier == '?' {
49 true
50 } else {
51 false
52 }
53 }
54}

Doing things with Generics

My initial idea was to simply make a generic struct as follows.

1#[derive(Debug, Clone)]
2struct SpfMechanism<T> {
3 qualifier: char,
4 mechanism: T,
5}

And then impliment the functions that would apply to all instance types of SpfMechanism. But as I sat thinking about it. I realised it wouldn't work. Because the as_mechanism() function would need to be able to differentiate between a redirect, include, and so on. I needed to be able to use as_mechanism and create records similar to include:_spf.example.com, ip4:X.X.X.X, a, mx:mx-host.example.com and so on.

I realised I would need to actually have a unique type/kind for each mechanism, and so I added an enum; listing the kinds of mechanisms

 1#[derive(Debug, Clone)]
 2enum MechanismKind {
 3 Include,
 4 Redirect,
 5 A,
 6 MX,
 7 IpV4,
 8 IpV6,
 9 All,
10}

And I updated the SpfMechanism to be

1#[derive(Debug, Clone)]
2struct SpfMechanism<T> {
3 kind: MechanismKind,
4 qualifier: char,
5 mechanism: T,
6}
7

Throw in a little magic so I can test the what Kind the SpfMechanism is:
Note: This was generated by my editor with a click of a button.

 1impl MechanismKind {
 2 /// Returns `true` if the mechanism_kind is [`Include`].
 3 fn is_include(&self) -> bool {
 4 matches!(self, Self::Include)
 5 }
 6 /// Returns `true` if the mechanism_kind is [`A`].
 7 fn is_a(&self) -> bool {
 8 matches!(self, Self::A)
 9 }
10
11 /// Returns `true` if the mechanism_kind is [`MX`].
12 fn is_mx(&self) -> bool {
13 matches!(self, Self::MX)
14 }
15
16 /// Returns `true` if the mechanism_kind is [`IpV4`].
17 fn is_ip_v4(&self) -> bool {
18 matches!(self, Self::IpV4)
19 }
20
21 /// Returns `true` if the mechanism_kind is [`IpV6`].
22 fn is_ip_v6(&self) -> bool {
23 matches!(self, Self::IpV6)
24 }
25
26 /// Returns `true` if the mechanism_kind is [`All`].
27 fn is_all(&self) -> bool {
28 matches!(self, Self::All)
29 }
30
31 /// Returns `true` if the mechanism_kind is [`Redirect`].
32 fn is_redirect(&self) -> bool {
33 matches!(self, Self::Redirect)
34 }
35}

Next I wanted to implement the functions that would be applied to all SpfMechanism irrespective of the mechanism type, be it String or IpNetwork

All mechanism types support these functions.

 1impl<T> SpfMechanism<T> {
 2 fn new(kind: MechanismKind, qualifier: char, mechanism: T) -> Self {
 3 Self {
 4 kind,
 5 qualifier,
 6 mechanism,
 7 }
 8 }
 9 fn is_pass(&self) -> bool {
10 self.qualifier == '+'
11 }
12 fn is_fail(&self) -> bool {
13 self.qualifier == '-'
14 }
15 fn is_softfail(&self) -> bool {
16 self.qualifier == '~'
17 }
18 fn is_neutral(&self) -> bool {
19 self.qualifier == '?'
20 }
21 fn mechanism_prefix_from_kind(&self) -> String {
22 let push_str = match self.kind {
23 MechanismKind::Redirect => "redirect=",
24 MechanismKind::Include => "include:",
25 MechanismKind::A => "a:", // requires modification
26 MechanismKind::MX => "mx:", // requires modication
27 MechanismKind::IpV4 => "ip4:",
28 MechanismKind::IpV6 => "ip6:",
29 MechanismKind::All => "",
30 };
31 push_str.to_string()
32 }
33}

The important thing to note here is that impl<T> is what makes these functions able to work no matter what <T> ultimately turns out to be.

Implementing SpfMechanism for redirect, include, a, and mx

These mechanism all share a common type of String for T but we do not need to recode the is_* functions. So we need to implement as_string() and as_mechanism() only at this time. You might noticed as you read through that as_mechanism() makes use of the mechanism_prefix_from_kind() function which is defined for the generic SpfMechanism

I also decided to implement new_* for each mechanism type. These are essentially aliases to SpfMechanism::new()

 1impl SpfMechanism<String> {
 2 fn new_include(qualifier: char, mechanism: String) -> Self {
 3 SpfMechanism::new(MechanismKind::Include, qualifier, mechanism)
 4 }
 5 fn new_redirect(qualifier: char, mechanism: String) -> Self {
 6 SpfMechanism::new(MechanismKind::Redirect, qualifier, mechanism)
 7 }
 8 fn new_all(qualifier: char, mechanism: String) -> Self {
 9 SpfMechanism::new(MechanismKind::All, qualifier, mechanism)
10 }
11 fn as_mechanism(&self) -> String {
12 // rebuild and return the string representation of a include, redirect, a or mx mechanism
13 let mut txt = String::new();
14 if self.qualifier != '+' {
15 txt.push(self.qualifier);
16 } else {
17 // Do nothing omitting '+'
18 }
19 if self.kind.is_all() {
20 txt.push_str("all")
21 } else {
22 txt.push_str(self.mechanism_prefix_from_kind().as_str());
23 txt.push_str(self.mechanism.as_str());
24 }
25 txt
26 }
27 fn as_string(&self) -> &String {
28 &self.mechanism
29 }
30}

The real payoff here is that we have a single as_mechanism() and as_string() which works for all SpfMechanism where <T> is of type String. Those being redirect, include a, mx and all. Within as_mechanism(), I call mechanism_prefix_from_kind() to get the correct prefix string, be it include:, redirect= and so on.

Implementing SpfMechanism for Ip4 and Ip6

Ip4 and Ip6 are both of type IpNetwork the only difference being they are written as ip4:X.X.X.X and ip6:xxxx:xxxx:...

 1impl SpfMechanism<IpNetwork> {
 2 fn new_ip4(qualifier: char, mechanism: IpNetwork) -> Self {
 3 SpfMechanism::new(MechanismKind::IpV4, qualifier, mechanism)
 4 }
 5 fn new_ip6(qualifier: char, mechanism: IpNetwork) -> Self {
 6 SpfMechanism::new(MechanismKind::IpV6, qualifier, mechanism)
 7 }
 8 fn as_mechanism(&self) -> String {
 9 // rebuild and return the string represensation of a include, redirect mechanism
10 let mut txt = String::new();
11 if self.qualifier != '+' {
12 txt.push(self.qualifier);
13 } else {
14 // Do nothing omitting '+'
15 }
16 txt.push_str(self.mechanism_prefix_from_kind().as_str());
17 txt.push_str(self.mechanism.to_string().as_str());
18 txt
19 }
20 fn as_string(&self) -> String {
21 self.mechanism.to_string()
22 }
23}

In my previous article I didn't actually implement the ip6: records. Now, using this more generic approach, by adding merely a few lines of code. I have been able to implement ip6

Test Output for _netblocks2.google.com

 1List of TXT records found for _netblocks2.google.com.
 2TXT Record 1:
 3v=spf1 ip6:2001:4860:4000::/36 ip6:2404:6800:4000::/36 ip6:2607:f8b0:4000::/36 ip6:2800:3f0:4000::/36 ip6:2a00:1450:4000::/36 ip6:2c0f:fb50:4000::/36 ~all
 4
 5Decontructing SPF Record
 6Spf1 { source: "v=spf1 ip6:2001:4860:4000::/36 ip6:2404:6800:4000::/36 ip6:2607:f8b0:4000::/36 ip6:2800:3f0:4000::/36 ip6:2a00:1450:4000::/36 ip6:2c0f:fb50:4000::/36 ~all", include: None, redirect: None, is_redirected: false, a: None, mx: None, ip4: None, ip6: Some([SpfMechanism { kind: IpV6, qualifier: '+', mechanism: V6(Ipv6Network { addr: 2001:4860:4000::, prefix: 36 }) }, SpfMechanism { kind: IpV6, qualifier: '+', mechanism: V6(Ipv6Network { addr: 2404:6800:4000::, prefix: 36 }) }, SpfMechanism { kind: IpV6, qualifier: '+', mechanism: V6(Ipv6Network { addr: 2607:f8b0:4000::, prefix: 36 }) }, SpfMechanism { kind: IpV6, qualifier: '+', mechanism: V6(Ipv6Network { addr: 2800:3f0:4000::, prefix: 36 }) }, SpfMechanism { kind: IpV6, qualifier: '+', mechanism: V6(Ipv6Network { addr: 2a00:1450:4000::, prefix: 36 }) }, SpfMechanism { kind: IpV6, qualifier: '+', mechanism: V6(Ipv6Network { addr: 2c0f:fb50:4000::, prefix: 36 }) }]), all_qualifier: '~' }
 7SPF1: v=spf1 ip6:2001:4860:4000::/36 ip6:2404:6800:4000::/36 ip6:2607:f8b0:4000::/36 ip6:2800:3f0:4000::/36 ip6:2a00:1450:4000::/36 ip6:2c0f:fb50:4000::/36 ~all
 8
 9There are no include elements
10There are no ip4 networks
11There are no ip4 spf records.
12List of ip6 networks/hosts:
132001:4860:4000::/36
142404:6800:4000::/36
152607:f8b0:4000::/36
162800:3f0:4000::/36
172a00:1450:4000::/36
182c0f:fb50:4000::/36
19
20List of ip6 mechanisms:
21ip6:2001:4860:4000::/36
22ip6:2404:6800:4000::/36
23ip6:2607:f8b0:4000::/36
24ip6:2800:3f0:4000::/36
25ip6:2a00:1450:4000::/36
26ip6:2c0f:fb50:4000::/36
27
28Is a redirect: false

Code

The code for this aritcle can be found here

Final thoughts and thanks.

First, I would like to thank the people in the rust discord for answering my questions and making suggestions.

Also, this might not be the best solution. Exploring traits might be another way to go about getting things done.

Next steps?
I will consider breaking this single file up into seperate files to make the management easier. And learning to write actual tests. Always better to catch issues early.
